scenarioDescription:
The LHS 1678 Exoplanetary System


Overview

LHS 1678 is a star with 0.34 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.33 times its radius. It is located 64.83 light years away from the solar system and is estimated to be 7 billion years old, as compared to the Sun which is roughly 4.6 billion years old.

LHS 1678 is known to have 2 exoplanets in orbit around it.


Exoplanets in the LHS 1678 system


LHS 1678 b

LHS 1678 b was discovered by the Transiting Exoplanet Survey Satellite (TESS) observatory, in 2021-10, using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is 0.01 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of LHS 1678 b is 0.350 times the mass of Earth. The radius of LHS 1678 b is 0.696 that of Earth. At less than 1.5 Earth masses, LHS 1678 b is a regular terrestrial planet, much like the terrestrial planets we find in our solar system, namely Mercury, Venus, Earth and Mars.


LHS 1678 c

LHS 1678 c was discovered by the Transiting Exoplanet Survey Satellite (TESS) observatory, in 2021-10, using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is 0.03 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of LHS 1678 c is 1.399 times the mass of Earth. The radius of LHS 1678 c is 0.982 that of Earth. At less than 1.5 Earth masses, LHS 1678 c is a regular terrestrial planet, much like the terrestrial planets we find in our solar system, namely Mercury, Venus, Earth and Mars.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanetary system LHS 1678, which contains 2 exoplanets and was discovered by the Transiting Exoplanet Survey Satellite (TESS).
name: LHS 1678 - System With 2 Exoplanets
